videos.title: The Unstoppable Rise Of LG TVs (There's No Catching Up)
videos.description: üí° Turn any idea into a production-ready app or website by describing it to AI. Dream it, and Lindy builds it from coding to QA. Try Lindy today using my link üëâüèª https://go.lindy.ai/logically-answered   In the early 2010s, OLED was a joke. Too fragile, too expensive, and impossible to scale. Everyone dropped it except LG. Fast forward to today, and LG owns over half the global OLED market. They even make panels for Samsung and Sony. So what did LG see that everyone else missed? Back in the 2000s, the TV world was all Plasma and LCD. Plasma had the best picture but came with heat, power, and burn-in issues. LCDs were cheap, efficient, and ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù While everyone chased scale, LG doubled down on quality. They bought Kodak‚Äôs OLED patents, poured billions into R&D, and invented WRGB OLED to cut costs. For years, it looked like financial suicide. But when Netflix, gaming, and home theaters exploded, OLED became the gold standard. By 2016, LG had perfected manufacturing, and by 2017, the C7 OLED changed everything. Competitors mocked OLED, then bought LG panels anyway. Now, LG Display supplies Samsung, Sony, and nearly every major brand. The bet no one believed in became the tech no one could live without. videos.title: The Unstoppable Rise Of LG TVs (There's No Catching Up)
videos.description: üí° Turn any idea into a production-ready app or website by describing it to AI. Dream it, and Lindy builds it from coding to QA. Try Lindy today using my link üëâüèª https://go.lindy.ai/logically-answered   In the early 2010s, OLED was a joke. Too fragile, too expensive, and impossible to scale. Everyone dropped it except LG. Fast forward to today, and LG owns over half the global OLED market. They even make panels for Samsung and Sony. So what did LG see that everyone else missed? Back in the 2000s, the TV world was all Plasma and LCD. Plasma had the best picture but came with heat, power, and burn-in issues. LCDs were cheap, efficient, and ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù While everyone chased scale, LG doubled down on quality. They bought Kodak‚Äôs OLED patents, poured billions into R&D, and invented WRGB OLED to cut costs. For years, it looked like financial suicide. But when Netflix, gaming, and home theaters exploded, OLED became the gold standard. By 2016, LG had perfected manufacturing, and by 2017, the C7 OLED changed everything. Competitors mocked OLED, then bought LG panels anyway. Now, LG Display supplies Samsung, Sony, and nearly every major brand. The bet no one believed in became the tech no one could live without. videos.title: The Unstoppable Rise Of LG TVs (There's No Catching Up)
videos.description: üí° Turn any idea into a production-ready app or website by describing it to AI. Dream it, and Lindy builds it from coding to QA. Try Lindy today using my link üëâüèª https://go.lindy.ai/logically-answered   In the early 2010s, OLED was a joke. Too fragile, too expensive, and impossible to scale. Everyone dropped it except LG. Fast forward to today, and LG owns over half the global OLED market. They even make panels for Samsung and Sony. So what did LG see that everyone else missed? Back in the 2000s, the TV world was all Plasma and LCD. Plasma had the best picture but came with heat, power, and burn-in issues. LCDs were cheap, efficient, and ‚Äúgood enough.‚Äù While everyone chased scale, LG doubled down on quality. They bought Kodak‚Äôs OLED patents, poured billions into R&D, and invented WRGB OLED to cut costs. For years, it looked like financial suicide. But when Netflix, gaming, and home theaters exploded, OLED became the gold standard. By 2016, LG had perfected manufacturing, and by 2017, the C7 OLED changed everything. Competitors mocked OLED, then bought LG panels anyway. Now, LG Display supplies Samsung, Sony, and nearly every major brand. The bet no one believed in became the tech no one could live without. comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.

comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.
comments.comment_text_original: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.
comments.comment_text_original: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. comments.comment_text_display:
to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.

comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.
comments.comment_text_original: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.
comments.comment_text_original: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. comments.comment_text_display:
to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

comments.comment_text_display: @MayukhNair Haha. Great question! Bought 2 right before I moved into my current home when they were on sale during Black Friday. The one from 2022 was naively purchased by Jimmy and wife thinking Samsung would've improved the software. And they did! Sorta, it was still bad, just different bad and just as laggy. Bought a Samsung OLED monitor from them last year, and they have the same freakin "smart OS" on their monitors that don't let you turn off Game Mode from auto-start up (which prevents USB-C ports on the monitor from being used at their full speed) without going through the service menu. Needless to say, I think I'm going to be leaning away from Samsung displays as new purchases for a while. üòÖ

Samsung was caught and lost a lawsuit for intentionally using electronics designed to fail just after the warranty. Every one of the six generations of Galaxy S phone I have owned had a different major hardware design flaw. Samsung appliances are known to be the least reliable overall brand. Their semiconductor manufacturing is a poor man's TSMC. My year-old Samsung tablet crashes the YouTube app every few days. Samsung is a garbage company with an impressively wide variety of poor quality products.
As an engineer, I think they should be ashamed at the quality of their engineering.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.
comments.comment_text_original:

comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.

comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.
comments.comment_text_original: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.
comments.comment_text_original: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. comments.comment_text_display:
to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.

comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.
comments.comment_text_original: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.
comments.comment_text_original: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. comments.comment_text_display:
to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.

We recently tested 6ghz in a large city and we couldn't see any other 6ghz radios except our own broadcasting.

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.
comments.comment_text_original:

comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.
comments.comment_text_original: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. comments.comment_text_display:
to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.
comments.comment_text_original:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years. 
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off. 

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.

comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.

comments.comment_text_display: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. The SoC is bad because they can get away with it, and the software is typical of Samsung, way tooover-bloatedd. They combine a weak and struggling SoC with a heavy and bloated OS. It is the same with their phones (mostly cheaper ones, but 3-year-old flagships struggle more than competitors too), there is no reason a 200$ phone needs 20GB+ of OS files and 15 services they need to connect to from the start. The TV would also probably run well if they just removed the 20 different ad-services they have on it by default.
comments.comment_text_original: It's an issue with both the SoC in the TV and Samsung's software. comments.comment_text_display:
to be clear the wifi connection isn't on 6, that's a backhaul/device comm channel, which is... normal-ish? for wifi 7 equipment when leadership/marketing drives instead of engineers. the... thinking... there is that since literally everything used in home construction (even non insulated interior walls with a half-inch sheet of drywall on either side) blocks 6ghz at consumer broadcast strengths the interference inside of a room will be pretty limited

there are a lot of real world problems with this series of assumptions but it's not quite insanity. it's really easy to get pretty quiet on 6ghz even in an apartment building.

comments.comment_text_display: As an owner of 3 Frame TVs (Non-Pro's from 2020 and 2022) due to the desire of "TVs that don't look like TVs". Everything Quinn said in this is true. Can't relate to the wireless portion since the Non-Pros use a cable to connect the box to the TV, but the Samsung software is atrocious, and is still not fixed. The "art mode" is NEVER consistent in turning on or off correctly after turning off connected devices. Software is dog-slow and Samsung is adamant on trying to make sure you pay for their art subscription for features that should be STANDARD on a TV focused on letting you display art at a premium price tag. The mounting method changed in 2022 I think? the original mount was at least long enough to get one screw onto a stud, but the new mount sucks. If I were to say anything positive, it's that it can be confused for art sometimes, and it definitely makes a room feel a little nicer. Idk if I'd ever pay for the "Pro" version though. The regular frames were already too expensive for what they are, and I feel like we'd all less harsh on these TVs if the price matched the frustration but it doesn't.

comments.comment_text_display: @MayukhNair Haha. Great question! Bought 2 right before I moved into my current home when they were on sale during Black Friday. The one from 2022 was naively purchased by Jimmy and wife thinking Samsung would've improved the software. And they did! Sorta, it was still bad, just different bad and just as laggy. Bought a Samsung OLED monitor from them last year, and they have the same freakin "smart OS" on their monitors that don't let you turn off Game Mode from auto-start up (which prevents USB-C ports on the monitor from being used at their full speed) without going through the service menu. Needless to say, I think I'm going to be leaning away from Samsung displays as new purchases for a while. üòÖ

Samsung was caught and lost a lawsuit for intentionally using electronics designed to fail just after the warranty. Every one of the six generations of Galaxy S phone I have owned had a different major hardware design flaw. Samsung appliances are known to be the least reliable overall brand. As an engineer, I think they should be ashamed at the quality of their engineering.

comments.comment_text_display:
I treated myself to a big screen TV in 2005. For $2500, I got a 50" DLP - specifically because I was capable of fixing it. It lasted me for 17 years.
Knowing that electronics prices are so volatile, I avoided looking at advertisements for a while. I did find out that 2 months later, the same TV was $500 less.
Fast forward a few years, I'm helping a friend of mine without a car get his new big screen home. I mentioned to the sales guy that I had a DLP TV, but hadn't seen any in a while. He said that he saw a couple in the dollar store around the corner ü•µ That jerk-off.

I am glad that I was able to repair my TV for so long, until parts ran out. I purchased the last colour wheel for the LG DLP TV line ever.

comments.comment_text_display: Don't buy a Samsung QDOLED unless you know and don't care about some major caveats that come with these TV's, specially for gaming. One of the many bad things about these TV's is that Samsung loves to destroy them with firmware updates that will download automatically even after you tell the tv not to. Another detail is that there isn't a proper HGIG implementation and nobody even knows how many nits to set it up, you will find many different numbers from experts that can range from a couple hundred nits below the actual peak brightness of the tv, to double the nits, and everyone is always sure that their numbers are the right ones. Also, the tv uses the P3 color space when in "HGIG" only because BT2020 is so bad, it's unusable without a professional calibration. So basically the 90% BT2020 coverage of these QDOLEDs is useless for gaming. Another problem is that every year Samsung comes up with a new bug and there is no way of knowing what it is (such as the color space bug for the 2025 models). If you are looking for a tv that will just work and you won't have to dig through forums to find how to fix it, then sadly you must look elsewhere.
